item.title: World of Warcraft Patch 11.2 Added a Secret Way to Skip Delves
item.description:
Using a secret function of the Reshii Wraps in World of Warcraft Patch 11.2, players can skip directly to the end of a Delve, drastically shortening the time it takes to complete them. Using this handy trick, fans can complete one of these World of Warcraft instances in a matter of minutes.

When it released on August 5, World of Warcraft Patch 11.2 added tons of new content to the game, including the zone of K’aresh, the Manaforge Omega raid, and an open world activity called Phase Diving. During the campaign, players can also obtain a powerful artifact cloak called the Reshii Wraps, which has a number of special features that can be unlocked via Ethereal Strands obtained in the campaign and endgame content.

WoW: The War Within Reshii Wraps Delve Skip Explained

However, this special cloak contains a secret ability that can occasionally let fans bypass Delves completely. The second upgrade of the Reshii Wraps in World of Warcraft , Secrets of the Depths, states that the wearer can “now access secret rooms in Delves.” In practice, this means Ethereal Portals have a chance to appear in a Delve, or spawn while interacting with a Flickergate. By using these gateways, players can bypass all the normal objectives in a Delve and head directly to the treasure room, completing the Delve in a fraction of the normal time.

All Reshii Wraps Upgrades in World of Warcraft

Upgrade

Features

Item Level

Boon of the Reshii

  • Role-specific Ethereal ability
  • Enables Phase Diving

701

Secrets of the Depths

  • Access Ethereal Portals in Delves
  • Find Phase Orbs while Phase Diving

707

Orbs of Power

  • Slain enemies in Phase Diving can drop Phase Orbs
  • Ground mounts accessible while Phase Diving

714

What Lies Beyond

  • Find Phase-Lost Exchequer chests while Phase Diving

720

Regalia of the Reshii

  • Power of the Reshii achievement
  • Reshii Hood and Reshii Mantle transmogs

730

Once entered, fans will find themselves in the Ethereal Routing Station. This room will feature a special objective that can range from clearing the room of monsters to fighting one or more bosses. After finishing this task, players can leave the Station and complete the Delve without any further encounters. What’s more, the Nemesis Chest at the end of the WoW Delve will automatically be maxed out, even if one did not fight any of the special Nemesis elite mobs within the instance.

Fans have been delighted by this new feature of the Reshii Wraps. Though these portals don’t always appear, occasionally having the option to swiftly finish a Delve is a wonderful surprise, and a great way to fill out the Great Vault, with some players completing the instances in as quickly as three minutes. What’s more, fans like Twitter user Grox have been delighted by the secret objectives, such as one that threw him against both Zekvir and the Underpin, the Delve Nemeses from WoW: The War Within Season 1 and 2 respectively.

World of Warcraft confirmed Midnight will be launching with 10 Delves, as well as a new Delve companion and Nemesis. It remains to be seen if the expansion will include a skip feature like these Ethereal Portals at some point in later seasons.

item.title: Fans Call Out Metal Gear Solid Delta Collector’s Edition ‘Trash’ Quality
item.description:
The $200 Collector's Edition of Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater is drawing criticism on social media over its contents, which reportedly include several items of questionable quality. Some fans have gone as far as to label these dubious Metal Gear Solid Delta goodies as "trash."

The MGS Delta: Snake Eater Collector's Edition was originally unveiled in June 2024, with its announcement coinciding with the start of the game's pre-orders. Among other things, Konami said the limited-edition package would include a miniature terrarium diorama depicting the opening scene of the Virtuous Mission, showing Naked Snake kneeling to accept a radio call from HQ.

MGS Delta Collector's Edition Buyer Baffled by 'Chuck Norris' Snake

With Metal Gear Solid Delta officially releasing on August 28, some Collector's Edition pre-orders have already reached their owners. A vocal share of them expressed dissatisfaction, particularly with the included terrarium. In one widely circulated Reddit post, user 1AmChris2 described the edition as "trash," arguing that the diorama’s figure bears little resemblance to the game's protagonist. The user cheekily added, "Snake is actually Chuck Norris?"

Apart from criticizing the low-quality rendition of the Metal Gear Solid Delta protagonist, 1AmChris2 also took issue with the terrarium itself, noting that the package did not include anything to attach the foliage to the diorama. As a result, they said they had to use their own glue to assemble it. Expressing disappointment, the fan concluded by saying they would not purchase any more collector’s editions from Konami. Their post amassed thousands of upvotes and emerged on the front page of the r/MetalGearSolid subreddit within hours of appearing on August 28, prompting hundreds of comments mocking the perceived lack of quality in the $200 package.

Another MGS Delta Owner Compares it to 'a Smack in the Face'

In another widely circulated post, Reddit user Mason12075 voiced similar frustrations with the Collector's Edition. "The foliage is not what they pictured initially," the fan said, describing it as "awful imitation moss stuff that looks worse in person and does anything but stay upright." They ultimately expressed regret over spending $200 on the edition, likening the experience to "a smack in the face."

Retailer listings reviewed by Game Rant indicate that the Metal Gear Solid Delta Collector's Edition is sold out in the United States as of August 29, with the exception of a sole Walmart reseller offering it for $309.99. Some stateside and international scalpers have already listed it on eBay, with prices starting at $275—a 37.5% markup. Despite controversy over the perceived lack of quality in the limited-edition package, the game itself appears to be off to a strong start, currently ranking as the best-selling paid title on Steam. Critics also appear to be loving it, with Metal Gear Solid Delta review scores falling just shy of the widely acclaimed original.

Source: Walmart

item.title: 5 Short Games To Play This Weekend (8/29 - 8/31)
item.description:
Closing out September are highly anticipated games like Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater and Lost Soul Aside , and there are even more heavy hitters coming in the next few weeks. Indeed, the likes of Hollow Knight Silksong and Silent Hill f are just around the corner.

But if you're looking for a more relaxed fit, perhaps something that you can cruise through in a weekend, then read on. The following games, some of which are bona fide classics, can be beaten in under ten hours, making them perfect stopgaps or appetizers before you delve into beefier titles like Borderlands 4 .

Sword of the Sea

Released just a few weeks ago, Sword of the Sea is an astonishing, hypnotizing game from the minds behind Abzu and The Pathless . Like those titles, Sword of the Sea can often feel more like a meditation than a nail-biting gameplay experience, although its interactive elements are still engaging and dynamic enough to keep it from feeling too passive. When it's firing on all cylinders, Sword of the Sea is quite magical indeed.

How Long To Beat Sword of the Sea

  • Main story: 3 hours
  • Completionist run: 8.5 hours

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Sword of the Sea
Adventure
Exploration

Developer(s)
Giant Squid
Publisher(s)
Giant Squid
Number of Players
Single-player
Steam Deck Compatibility
Unknown
PC Release Date
August 19, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

Surf across magnificent waves of sand and glistening waters on an epic quest to restore a lost ocean in Sword of the Sea.
From the visionary artist behind ABZÛ, The Pathless, and Journey – Sword of the Sea is an atmospheric surfing adventure with highspeed Hoversword movement inspired by skateboarding and snowboarding.

Awesome Surfing and Tricks
Carve your way forward on the ancient and powerful Hoversword, which moves like a snowboard, skateboard, and surfboard all in one. Build momentum to reach top speed and catch big air off the crests of giant waves. Pull off radical flips, spins, and grab tricks with ease as you shred halfpipes, ramps, and wall rides. It’s the perfect balance of exhilarating action and fluid, meditative movement.

A Mysterious and Visually Stunning World of Waves
Explore a world where the land flows in constant waves. From massive tides to the smallest ripples, the shifting sea of dunes is incredibly detailed and beautifully rendered. Surf across sandy deserts, glacial mountains, and many more undulating environments full of secrets in this incredible adventure.

A Spiritual Journey to Unveil the Sea
You are the Wraith – resurrected in the desolate Necropolis on a quest to unveil the ancient sea buried beneath the land. Discover the remnants of a lost culture hidden in sinking tombs and skatepark-like ruins as you search for purpose. Transform sandy dunes into glittering, emerald waters and witness magical sealife return in huge, breathtaking shoals. Feel the spiritual magic of surfing as you connect with nature and restore life – but beware, there is also darkness lurking under the waves.

A Legacy of Art, Design, and Music Continues
Developed by the renowned indie team Giant Squid, Sword of the Sea features the unique artistic design of creative director Matt Nava and beautiful music composed by Austin Wintory. Long time creative partners, their works together include beloved indie games ABZÛ, The Pathless, and the legendary, award-winning game Journey.

PS5 Release Date
August 19, 2025
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 5
PS Plus Availability
Extra & Premium
Powered by

Indika

What a bizarre game Indika is. It follows a nun who struggles with mental health and temptation, but the story's surreal presentation and dialog, along with its exuberant, gleefully disturbed writing, takes it from good to unforgettable. Video games so rarely follow characters like Indika's protagonist—women, nuns, noncombatants, et cetera—which adds additional novelty to its psychotic world. If you're burnt out on combat but still want a cinematic, captivating narrative, then Indika is right up your alley.

How Long to Beat Indika

  • Main story: 4 hours
  • Completionist run: 5 hours

Engine
Unreal Engine 4

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

MEET A NOT-SO-ORDINARY NUN: INDIKA is a third-person, story-driven game set in a strange world where religious visions clash with harsh reality. It tells the story of a young nun who sets off on a journey of self-discovery with the most unusual, horn-headed companion by her side.

On the outside, Indika seems to be a typical nun attempting to adjust to a difficult and monotonous monastery life. Humble and innocent in her appearance, do not be deceived as this young girl has also made a highly unlikely acquaintance—as she speaks with the devil himself.

Indika’s unusual connection with the Evil One leads her on an errand beyond the safe walls of the monastery. The world she discovers can only be described as a wild combination of comedy and tragedy straight out of the novels by Dostoyevski and Bulhakov.


ENJOY AN INDIE GAME WHERE EVERYTHING GOES: The subjects of religion and authority are prevalent throughout Indika’s journey and she’ll be faced with many questions along the way. Guide her to find the answers one by one before she can finish her life-defining odyssey.

Odd Meter is a small, independent studio formerly based in Moscow and now operating out of Kazakhstan. Its members put aesthetics at the forefront and aren’t afraid to tread the fine line of ethical norms. Their game is a great testament to that, as INDIKA constitutes an open challenge to the industry's established approach to creating video games.

Powered by

A Way Out

Before It Takes Two and Split Fiction , Hazelight Studios birthed A Way Out , a game that is often misunderstood and underappreciated. To be fair, it's clear that Hazelight hadn't quite hit its stride at the time of A Way Out 's development: it is certainly not as good as the studio's other co-op outings. But remarkably, it retains the fundamentally cooperative mechanics of its successors, only within a more grounded story about two men attempting to escape prison. Because of this premise, A Way Out is nowhere near as charming or boundlessly creative as Hazelight's modern works, but it's undeniably fun at times, and a fascinating look into Hazelight's earlier work.

How Long to Beat A Way Out

  • Main story 6.5 hours
  • Completionist: 6.5 hours

From the creators of Brothers – A Tale of Two Sons comes A Way Out, an exclusively co-op adventure where you play the role of one of two prisoners making their daring escape from prison.

What begins as a thrilling breakout quickly turns into an unpredictable, emotional adventure unlike anything seen or played before.

A Way Out is an experience that must be played with two players. Each player controls one of the main characters, Leo and Vincent, in a reluctant alliance to break out of prison and gain their freedom.

Play the entire experience with your friends for free using the friends pass free trial feature. When you purchase the full game, you can invite any of your friends online regardless of whether or not they’ve purchased the game. From the in-game menu, send them an invite, they’ll unlock the Free Trial, and then you’re ready to play the entire experience together.

Multiplayer

Portal

The younger generation of gamers may overlook Portal ; it's certainly not a contemporary franchise, thanks to Valve's allergy to the number three. But although it's getting on in years, it's still one of the best puzzle games ever made, with a delightfully simple gameplay premise that's milked for nearly all it's worth by the time the end credits roll. It's a sterling example of Valve's ingenuity as a developer, and a must-play for just about any kind of gamer. But be warned: you will want to play Portal 2 , and you will eventually be sad about the lack of a Portal 3 .

How Long to Beat Portal

  • Main story: 3 hours
  • Completionist run: 10.5 hours

Portal is a new single player game from Valve. Set in the mysterious Aperture Science Laboratories, Portal has been called one of the most innovative new games on the horizon and will offer gamers hours of unique gameplay.

The game is designed to change the way players approach, manipulate, and surmise the possibilities in a given environment; similar to how Half-Life 2's Gravity Gun innovated new ways to leverage an object in any given situation.

Players must solve physical puzzles and challenges by opening portals to maneuvering objects, and themselves, through space.

Platform(s)
PC, PS3, Switch, Xbox 360
How Long To Beat
3 Hours
Powered by

Flower

Though it's best known for Journey and the more recent Sky: Children of the Light , Thatgamecompany's 2007 release, Flower , is more than worth a look. Players take control of a mystical, floating flower petal at the start of each level, and they must fly about using the PlayStation controller's gyro controls and help other flowers bloom. Over time, the single petal is joined by others, turning the player's avatar into an ethereal, overwhelming force for life, growth, and beauty. It's one of the most ingenious and refreshing games of the PS3 era, and is still unique all these years later.

How Long to Beat Flower

  • Main story: 2 hours
  • Completionist run: 5 hours

Part of the first permanent video game collection at the Smithsonian, experience award-winning Flower, now available on PC. Flower lets you take control of the wind as you explore and navigate beautiful, lush environments. Journey through varied landscapes at your own pace, interacting with and changing the environment as you go, and find balance and harmony in your surroundings.

This is an interactive escape that takes you on an emotional journey like no other game you've ever experienced.

Simple Gameplay Controls – Controlling the game is as simple as guiding the wind in the direction you want to go. Lush and Interactive Environments – Vast grassy fields, blowing in the breeze, create a lush, immersive environment.

Immersive and Emotional – Accessible to gamers and non-gamers alike, the game takes players on an incredibly personal and emotional experience.

item.title: What Baldur's Gate 3 Fans Should Know Before Playing Dungeons and Dragons for the First Time
item.description:
Baldur’s Gate 3 has introduced thousands of new players to the world of tabletop roleplaying, giving many their first taste of Dungeons & Dragons . The game brilliantly captures the spirit of rolling dice, making tough decisions, and weaving a story alongside a cast of companions. But for all the ways Larian Studios’ masterpiece echoes the tabletop experience, some major differences can surprise players when they finally sit down at the table.

The transition from a polished, cinematic CRPG to the boundless unpredictability of D&D can be both exciting and overwhelming. While Baldur’s Gate 3 offers a streamlined version of the 5th Edition rules, a DM-led campaign has a level of flexibility (and sometimes chaos) that even the best video games can’t replicate. Understanding what’s similar, what’s different, and where expectations need adjusting is key to enjoying D&D as more than just BG3 without the cutscenes. For new adventurers making the leap, here’s a breakdown of the biggest rule changes, roleplay differences, and mindset shifts that will help bridge the gap between Baldur’s Gate 3 and the tabletop game it’s based on.

What’s Familiar: Why BG3 Players Have a Head Start When Playing Dungeons & Dragons

Baldur’s Gate 3 may not teach everything a player needs to know about Dungeons & Dragons , but it does give fans a pretty solid foundation. The rules of the game, the rhythm of combat, and the spirit of roleplay all carry over, meaning BG3 players won’t feel like complete newcomers when sitting down at their first session.

Structural and Technical Similarities

Luckily, BG3 players have the basics under wraps. Players who have undertaken a Baldur’s Gate 3 playthrough come to the D&D table knowing all the technical details that might challenge total newbies. The core mechanics of Baldur’s Gate 3 have 5e written all over them: making dice rolls, advantage/disadvantage modifiers, classes, subclasses, spell slots, and ability checks second nature to BG3 players who have swapped the controller for a dice tray.

Similarly, the combat structure of a D&D game should feel all too familiar. When in combat, players are faced with turn-based initiative, actions, bonus actions, and movement that will remind them of some of the best fights in Baldur’s Gate 3 .

Roleplaying Is at the Heart of D&D and BG3

If roleplaying in BG3 as a Tav or Durge was a highlight for a player, that player will probably excel in playing D&D . Dialogue choices, background stories, and companion interactions in BG3 serve as training wheels for collaborative storytelling. While D&D doesn’t have a dialogue wheel, it thrives on the same core idea: knowing a character so well that players get to make choices that shape the world around them.

Party Dynamics and Teamwork

Another familiar element is the emphasis on the party. In BG3 , success depends on building a balanced team, leaning on different strengths, and combining abilities to overcome challenges. It came naturally to most players, especially given the fact that BG3 ’s cast of characters is so memorable and diverse. D&D is no different. Teamwork is critical, memorable characters will stand out, and players who understand how to complement one another’s abilities will thrive. BG3 veterans already know the importance of a well-timed Guidance cantrip, a rogue who scouts ahead, or a cleric who keeps everyone standing.

Where Things Differ: Dungeons & Dragons vs. Baldur’s Gate 3

Players of Baldur’s Gate 3 enjoy a significant edge over those who have never played the game when it comes to translating skills into D&D . However, not all is the same. The differences between a video game and a living, breathing tabletop campaign can be just as striking as the similarities. This difference is often what makes D&D so challenging and yet rewarding.

The Dungeon Master

In Baldur’s Gate 3 , Larian Studios was the Dungeon Master. Through the Narrator voiced by Amelia Tyler, players interacted with the world and were presented with the gameplay and role-playing options. In tabletop D&D, the DM fills that role. But unlike a video game, no script or coded responses limit the experience. The Dungeon Master has the power to change encounters, invent NPCs on the fly, or bend the rules for the sake of storytelling. Instead of pre-written dialogue options, players can try absolutely anything and see how the DM responds. This narrative give-and-take is one of the best aspects of a D&D campaign.

No Save Scumming

Players who have avoided Baldur’s Gate 3 ’s Honour Mode have likely depended on save scumming before. An unlucky roll, a fight not going as planned, or disapproval from a cherished companion may prompt a quick rewind to avoid consequences. But at the D&D table, there’s no reloading a save file.

Once a dice roll hits the table, the outcome stands—good or bad. This can feel harsh at first, but it also makes victories that much more satisfying, since nothing can be undone or replayed until it works out perfectly. Sometimes, with enough Inspiration Points, players may have the chance to test their luck again. But most decisions and missteps are simply final.

Exploration and Freedom

The world of Baldur’s Gate 3 unfolds across three Acts, each vastly different from the others. However, this variety is scripted. Although the world that Larian created may seem expansive and alive, it was carefully designed within certain coded limits. Players are definitely rewarded for their creative thinking, but every so-called “unpredictable” or uncouth approach to a problem was planned for in advance during development. Solutions for different situations were thought of from the start. And ultimately, the borders of a map define what exploration is possible in Baldur’s Gate 3 .

At a D&D tabletop, players get a taste of true freedom. As the Dungeon Master commits to building the D&D campaign, players are free to try anything, even break the plot. As long as the DM allows players to run wild, in a truly chaotic campaign, anything can happen.

Rest Mechanics

BG3 players are used to the convenience of long rests and the magical replenishment of spell slots at the click of a button. In D&D , resting is far less predictable. Long rests may not always be available, and a DM can introduce consequences for overusing them, such as missed encounters, story complications, or ambushes. Resource management becomes increasingly pressing, too, with the lack of endless food or BG3 camp supplies. D&D players must strategize about when to push forward and when to take a breather.

Death

Death is immediately reversible in Baldur’s Gate 3 . Whether through a quick plea to Withers or a Scroll of Revivify tucked away in a backpack, most losses are temporary. While reviving characters in BG3 is a given, at the D&D table, death carries more weight. While resurrection spells exist, they’re not guaranteed. Components can be costly, failure chances can be high, and sometimes a DM may rule that a character's death is final. The result is a higher sense of risk and emotional payoff, where every dangerous fight carries real consequences.

item.title: The Wait For Silksong Was Long, But These Games Took Even Longer
item.description:
The world of gaming has always been defined by anticipation. Few things capture the imagination of players more than a long-awaited release, with years of speculation, rumors, and shifting development shaping expectations, with some delays becoming almost as famous as the games themselves.

While Hollow Knight: Silksong has built its own reputation for being elusive, it is hardly the first game to leave fans waiting year after year. From ambitious sequels to troubled reboots, many releases proved that sometimes the journey to launch is just as dramatic as the stories within the games themselves.

8 The Last Guardian

A Decade In The Shadows

The Last Guardian
7 /10
9.5 /10
Released
December 6, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Blood, Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
JapanStudio, GenDesign
Platform(s)
PlayStation 4
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

First announced in 2009 as the next project from Team Ico, The Last Guardian immediately captured attention with its striking imagery of a boy and his towering companion, Trico. Fans expected a release not long after, following the acclaim of Ico and Shadow of the Colossus.

Instead, years of technical setbacks, engine struggles, and studio reshuffling left the game adrift in development hell, and by the time it finally launched in 2016, The Last Guardian had been in development for over seven years. Despite the rocky journey, its emotional narrative and gorgeous aesthetics proved that some things are worth waiting for.

7 Cyberpunk 2077

Igniting Hype For A New Icon

6 Images
6 Images
Cyberpunk 2077
6 /10
113
9.0 /10
Released
December 10, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs and Alcohol
Developer(s)
CD Projekt Red
Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch 2, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

CD Projekt Red first teased Cyberpunk 2077 in 2012, promising a dense, futuristic RPG that sent expectations through the roof. However, years of silence, shifting release dates, and ambitious promises created one of the longest hype cycles in modern gaming that left many wondering if it would ever be released.

When the game finally arrived in 2020, it was met with both praise for its storytelling and criticism for its technical issues. Yet after many patches and expansions, the game has been brought closer to its lofty vision, now standing as one of the best open-world RPGs in recent memory.

6 Duke Nukem Forever

The King Of Delays

Duke Nukem Forever
4 /10
Released
June 14, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
3D Realms
Platform(s)
PS3, Xbox 360, PC
Powered by

Originally announced in 1997, Duke Nukem Forever holds the dubious honor of being the most infamous delayed game of all time. Promising to bring the wise-cracking hero into the modern FPS landscape, the game was rebooted repeatedly across multiple engines and development teams, being stuck in a loop from which it couldn't escape.

It wasn’t until 2011, 14 years after its announcement, that Duke Nukem Forever was finally released. Unfortunately, the game felt like a relic of its era, filled with outdated design choices, and while it failed to meet expectations, it remains a cultural touchstone for what “development hell” means in the gaming industry.

5 Team Fortress 2

Memed Into The Ground

Team Fortress 2
9.0 /10
Released
October 10, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence
Developer(s)
Valve
Platform(s)
PC, PS3, Xbox 360, Linux, macOS
Powered by

Valve first revealed Team Fortress 2 in 1998 as a realistic, tactical military shooter, but over time, the concept shifted dramatically, with the game enduring silence and numerous engine changes before finally seeing it launch in 2007 with its now-iconic cartoonish art style.

The wait proved worthwhile, and the game quickly became one of the most influential multiplayer shooters of all time, popularizing class-based combat and setting the standard for live-service support. Gaben himself even joked about the development time, stating that "hopefully it was worth the wait," and for many, it certainly was.

4 Prey 2006/2017

Reinvented Twice Over

6 Images
6 Images
Prey (2006)
7.0 /10
Released
July 11, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
Human Head Studios, 3D Realms, Venom Games
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox (Original), Xbox 360, Xbox One
Powered by

The journey of Prey is unusual, as it involves both the original 2006 game and its reboot in 2017. First announced in 1995, with development dragging on for over a decade before finally releasing in 2006 as a sci-fi shooter, the game was then slated to receive a sequel, which unfortunately suffered from the same curse as the original.

Instead, Arkane Studios reimagined the game entirely, launching a new Prey in 2017 after several years of development uncertainty. While radically different from its predecessor, it delivered a deep, immersive experience that justified the long road from the franchise’s initial announcement.

3 Skull And Bones

A Ship Lost At Sea

Skull and Bones

Ubisoft announced Skull and Bones at E3 2017, pitching it as a pirate-themed multiplayer experience inspired by Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag . Fans were excited to see the naval combat system evolve into a full game, yet after that announcement, the project became mired in redesigns, delays, and missed deadlines.

Years later, Skull and Bones still struggled to reach players, with multiple release dates pushed back, and when it finally arrived in 2024, the long development cycle had tempered some of the excitement. The game still has a long way to go, but with updates rolling in, the ultimate pirate fantasy is just around the corner.

2 Too Human

Missing The Hype Train

Too Human
Action RPG
Systems
Released
August 19, 2008

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Blood, Language, Mild Suggestive Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
Silicon Knights
Platform(s)
Xbox 360
Powered by

First revealed in 1999 as a PlayStation project, Too Human shifted platforms multiple times, eventually landing on Xbox 360. Promising an ambitious sci-fi action RPG that combined Norse mythology with futuristic technology, it was hyped as a massive trilogy that would revolutionize the gaming world.

By the time it was released in 2008, almost a decade had passed, and unfortunately, the game was met with a lukewarm reception and failed to spark the franchise it had promised. Its long road to release ultimately became more memorable than the game itself, and its legacy is more focused on the build-up than the actual launch.

1 Dead Island 2

Bringing A Franchise Back From The Dead

Powered by

Announced at E3 2014, Dead Island 2 immediately made an impression with its stylish trailer and continuation of a beloved series. However, the game quickly fell into development turmoil, shifting between multiple studios and disappearing from the spotlight for years, with many fans believing it to be canceled entirely.

Shockingly, Dead Island 2 resurfaced years later and was finally released in 2023, nearly nine years after its initial announcement. While not revolutionary, it delivered chaotic, gory fun and proved that even games left for dead can eventually find their way into players’ hands.
